author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Confronting Racist Marketing
description: Facebook takes on political ads, and (some) small businesses catch a break in aid funding.
content: Good morning! This is the most I’ve ever looked forward to a Monday, when New York City enters Phase 2 of its reopening. (Outdoor dining, here we come.) Here’s what else you need to know for the week ahead in business and tech news. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu and Reid J. Epstein
title: Fact-Checking Trump’s Tulsa Rally: Covid-19, Protesters and Biden
description: In his first rally in months, President Trump made multiple statements that were false, misleading or lacked evidence.
content: In his first mass rally in months, President Trump touched on everything from the coronavirus pandemic to military spending to former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., the presumptive Democratic nominee. Here’s a fact-check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Shane Goldmacher
title: Biden’s $80.8 Million Outpaced Trump’s Fund-Raising in May
description: It was a reversal of fortunes for the former vice president and a testament to the advantages of his first full month of fund-raising in concert with the Democratic National Committee.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr., whose campaign had long struggled to raise money, zoomed past President Trump’s fund-raising machine in May for the first time, pulling in $80.8 million together with the Democratic National Committee, about 10 percent more than the $74 million that Mr. Trump raised with the Republican Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Bound to Be of Use
description: Sid Sivakumar asks us to use our detective skills.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Monday puzzles usually have straightforward themes, and this New York Times debut by Sid Sivakumar is mostly straightforward in the sense that the clues lead directly to the answers. Even that question mark clue at 17A is not that bad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz, Kellen Browning and Sheera Frenkel
title: TikTok Teens and K-Pop Stans Say They Sank Trump Rally
description: Did a successful prank inflate attendance expectations for President Trump’s rally in Tulsa, Okla.?
content: President Trump’s campaign promised huge crowds at his rally in Tulsa, Okla., on Saturday, but it failed to deliver. Hundreds of teenage TikTok users and K-pop fans say they’re at least partially responsible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Todd May and George Yancy
title: Policing Is Doing What It Was Meant to Do. That’s the Problem.
description: Blaming racist violence on “bad apples” misses the point.
content: On June 6, one of us attended a memorial vigil for George Floyd. The opening speaker first thanked the local Police Department for keeping the vigil safe and then went on to distinguish between the majority of police officers who do their job helping and protecting people and the few who are racist and violent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Preet Bharara
title: The Wrong Justice Department Official Lost His Job This Weekend
description: The attorney general, Bill Barr, undermined the rule of law by forcing out Geoffrey Berman, the United States attorney in Manhattan.
content: President Trump has long made clear that, for him, “rule of law” is a limited-utility slogan. By word and deed, he has demonstrated his belief that the law and its instrumentalities exist to serve him, personally and politically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Pendleton
title: Op-Art: See the Sin
description: A sketch from an artist known for his critical articulations of blackness, abstraction and the avant-garde.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Public Health Experts Reject President’s View of Fading Pandemic
description: Contrary to President Trump’s recent comments, specialists say, recent increases are real, and the virus is like a “forest fire” that will burn as long as there is fuel.
content: Public health experts warned on Sunday that the coronavirus pandemic is not going away anytime soon. They directly contradicted President Trump’s promise that the disease that has infected more than two million Americans would “fade away” and his remarks that disparaged the value of evidence from coronavirus tests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Azzopardi
title: 6 Movies That Take Place in a Single Location (Mostly)
description: With the release of “7500” on Amazon Prime Video, here’s a look at a handful of films that create dramatic tension in one space (or outer space).
content: As we emerge from state-ordered quarantine, consider this: In movies, a locked-down set is often an artistic choice (or sometimes the result of a strapped budget). Some filmmakers find the challenges of these limitations to be a thrill in itself; for others, intimate spaces simply better serve the story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassidy George
title: Queer Butoh: Finding Belonging in the Dance of Darkness
description: “People who feel different feel at home in Butoh,” said the founder of an annual performance series, which this year will take place online.
content: The performance series Queer Butoh may seem as if it were marrying two disparate things. But queerness has informed Butoh — an avant-garde movement, born in Japan after World War II — since its inception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Ware
title: Spike Lee Saved My Life
description: How lessons from the director’s films prepared one moviegoer for a terrifying encounter with the police.
content: I was raised by an overprotective single mother. She did her best to prepare me for the realities of being a black man in America, but she also made sure to let me know that not everyone white was a racist. Still, she was terrified of one group of people: the police. And of her son encountering them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: On North Korea and Iran, Bolton Blames ‘the Split Between Trump and Trump’
description: In his memoir, the hawkish national security adviser describes a president who simultaneously wanted to sound tough and strike a deal — any deal — that he could portray as a victory.
content: President Trump knew exactly what he was getting when he hired John R. Bolton in the spring of 2018 to be his national security adviser: an uber-hawk who made no secret of his belief that Iran and North Korea could be driven over the brink by extreme sanctions, and who told the president that attacking nuclear facilities “might be the only lasting solution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Sally Banes, Distinguished Dance Critic and Historian, Dies at 69
description: Her writing paired a vivid and inquisitive approach with a lack of agenda and a belief that dance was a crucial part of cultural history.
content: Sally Banes, an influential dance historian and critic whose books include the indispensable “Terpsichore in Sneakers: Post-Modern Dance,” died on June 14 in Philadelphia. She was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Letícia Casado, Manuela Andreoni and Ernesto Londoño
title: Brazilian Ex-Minister Makes Quick Exit to U.S. as Inquiries Rattle Government
description: In a tumultuous week for President Jair Bolsonaro, his education minister resigned and landed in Miami under the cloud of a criminal investigation.
content: BRASÍLIA — It was the apex of one of the most tumultuous weeks of Jair Bolsonaro’s presidency. A flurry of arrests and judicial orders targeting supporters of the Brazilian leader plunged the capital into crisis as the country's coronavirus caseload surpassed one million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Minneapolis Shooting Leaves 1 Dead and 11 Wounded, Police Say
description: The shooting happened early Sunday morning in the city’s Uptown neighborhood, near the site of protests over the death of George Floyd.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — One person was killed and 11 wounded in a shooting in Minneapolis early on Sunday morning, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Brazil and the U.S. Drive New Coronavirus Infections
description: The W.H.O. reported more than 183,000 new cases, the largest one-day increase so far, as the global tally inched toward nine million. A Trump administration official said the White House was preparing for a potential wave of infections in the fall.
content: Peter Navarro, the White House director of trade and manufacturing policy, said in an interview on Sunday that the White House was working to prepare for the possibility of a second wave of the coronavirus in the fall, though he said it wouldn’t necessarily come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Roosevelt Statue to Be Removed From Museum of Natural History
description: The equestrian memorial to Theodore Roosevelt has long prompted objections as a symbol of colonialism and racism.
content: The bronze statue of Theodore Roosevelt, on horseback and flanked by a Native American man and an African man, which has presided over the entrance to the American Museum of Natural History in New York since 1940, is coming down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Jail Only Allowed White Staff to Guard Ex-Officer Charged With Killing George Floyd
description: Eight correctional officers said people of color who work in the jail were initially moved away from Derek Chauvin, the officer accused of killing George Floyd.
content: ST. PAUL, Minn. — Staff members working at the jail that held Derek Chauvin, the white officer charged with murder in the killing of George Floyd, say that only white employees were allowed to guard him when he was first brought to the facility last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benedict Carey
title: Tsunami or Ripple? The Pandemic’s Mental Toll Is an Open Question
description: Some health officials have forecast a steep rise in new mental health disorders. Others say the impact isn’t likely to last.
content: The psychological fallout from the coronavirus pandemic has yet to fully show itself, but some experts have forecast a tsunami of new disorders, and news accounts have amplified that message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Public Employees Are Accused of Vandalizing Black Lives Matter Sign
description: A Sheriff’s Office worker and an investigative assistant with the District Attorney’s Office in Ventura County, Calif., were arrested after the authorities reviewed footage from a surveillance camera.
content: A Sheriff’s Office employee and an investigative assistant with the District Attorney’s Office in Ventura County, Calif., were among three people who have been arrested after they were caught on video damaging a roadside Black Lives Matter sign, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Black Gallerists Press Forward Despite a Market That Holds Them Back
description: As Art Basel opens online, African-American galleries are glaringly absent.
content: Art Basel’s online viewing rooms went live on Thursday, presenting 281 of the world’s leading modern and contemporary art galleries.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 21, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 21, 2020.
content: An article on Page 6 about the first Pride march refers incompletely to the event’s organizers. They included Brenda Howard, Craig Rodwell, Fred Sargeant, Ellen Broidy and Linda Rhodes; Ms. Howard was not the sole organizer. The article also omitted a word from the title of a book by Chiké Frankie Edozien. The title is “Lives of Great Men: Living and Loving as an African Gay Man,” not “Lives of Great: Living and Loving as an African Gay Man.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Camp Would Frequently Bring Us Into Manhattan for Field Trips’
description: A planned reunion in Washington Square Park, a dropped book and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Hilary Moss
title: Revel in a Week of Theater and Storytelling
description: Continue celebrating Pride, experience Molière’s work live and finish off the week by watching playful pandas.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern).
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Facing the Wind’
description: Amid a pandemic and protests, one father decides to tell his children the truths he had been afraid to tell them until now.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Monmouth University to Remove Woodrow Wilson’s Name From Building
description: “Wilson was a controversial politician, and I think it has heightened awareness in 2020 about some of his racist policies,” said the president of the university, which is in New Jersey.
content: Monmouth University in New Jersey said it would remove Woodrow Wilson’s name from its marquee building after administrators, professors and students said that the former president held abhorrent views on race and reinstituted segregation in the federal work force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: N.Y.C. Hired 3,000 Workers for Contact Tracing. It’s Off to a Slow Start.
description: The program is crucial to the next phase of reopening, which begins on Monday. But workers have not had much success in getting information from people who test positive.
content: New York City’s ambitious contact-tracing program, a crucial initiative in the effort to curb the coronavirus, has gotten off to a worrisome start just as the city’s reopening enters a new phase on Monday, with outdoor dining, in-store shopping and office work resuming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: U.S.-China Feud, Hong Kong, Bullfighting: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: U.S.-China Feud, Hong Kong, Bullfighting: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Shooting in Seattle Raises Worries; Video Catches Calif. Sign Vandals
description: Prison guards in Minnesota say only whites were allowed to guard Derek Chauvin, the officer who knelt on George Floyd’s neck, when he was first taken to jail.
content: This briefing has ended. Read the latest coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Christina Morales
title: Professor Who Asked Student to ‘Anglicize’ Her Name Is Put on Leave
description: Matthew Hubbard, a mathematics professor in Oakland, Calif., said his emails to Phuc Bui Diem Nguyen, a Vietnamese-American college freshman, were both a “mistake” and “offensive.”
content: A community college professor in Oakland, Calif., is on administrative leave after asking a Vietnamese-American student to “Anglicize” her name because he felt it sounded “offensive” in English.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Kelley
title: What if the Supreme Court Rules on Abortion and the Country Shrugs?
description: There’s a potentially catastrophic decision coming. If you’ve struggled to focus on it, I don’t blame you.
content: Remember early March — that week or so before we fully grasped how much our lives were about to change? I was in Washington, D.C., to attend what turned out to be one of the last in-person oral arguments at the Supreme Court for the foreseeable future — the big abortion case out of Louisiana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Why Is OSHA AWOL?
description: Worker protections are critical during the pandemic — yet the Trump administration has issued only voluntary guidance instead of enforceable rules.
content: As states and municipalities relax shelter-in-place orders, the nation seems to be racing to get the economy back to something resembling the pre-pandemic era. Restaurants, malls, cinemas, day care centers and retail stores are reopening sooner than most medical professionals think is wise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Bullfighting, Already Ailing in Spain, Is Battered by Lockdown
description: A storied tradition has been weakened by animal rights concerns. With the pandemic halting bullfights, breeders and others face hard choices.
content: ALMADÉN DE LA PLATA, Spain — Extremeño, an imposing black bull who weighs more than half a ton, was set to fight to death next month in the neoclassical ring of the Spanish city of Valencia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Mihir Zaveri
title: After Video Shows Apparent Chokehold, N.Y.P.D. Suspends Officer
description: The encounter between a black man and the police on the Rockaway boardwalk came days after lawmakers made the use of chokeholds a criminal offense.
content: The New York Police Department on Sunday suspended a police officer who was involved in the arrest of a black man in Queens, after cellphone video of the encounter showed the officer appearing to use an illegal chokehold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Suhasini Raj
title: 8 Hospitals in 15 Hours: A Pregnant Woman’s Crisis in the Pandemic
description: Her baby was coming, and her complications were growing more dangerous. But nowhere would take her — an increasingly common story as India’s health care system buckles under pressure.
content: NEW DELHI — Neelam Kumari Gautam woke up at 5 a.m. with shooting labor pains. Her husband put her gently in the back of a rickshaw and motored with her to a hospital. Then another. Then another. Her pain was so intense she could barely breathe, but none would take her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: As Symbols of the Confederacy Fall, Activists Say Mississippi’s Flag Should Be Next
description: A renewed challenge to the state flag, the only one with the Confederate battle flag embedded in it, has stirred a familiar debate between tradition and changed views on race.
content: ATLANTA — Five years ago, in the wake of the horrific massacre of black parishioners by a white supremacist at a South Carolina church, the University of Mississippi lowered the state flag for the last time on campus as Confederate symbols were being brought down across the South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Milton Esterow
title: Music From the Death Camps: Alive and Being Readied for a New Home
description: With the help of the Italian government, and others, a musician is working to build a home for an archive of works composed in Nazi concentration camps.
content: For months, Francesco Lotoro was forced to stay in his home, quarantined by a virus that ravaged his country, Italy, and slowed a project he has been working on since 2014. His dream is to build a study center to house an archive of concentration camp music from World War II, a trove he has been collecting for 30 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Gabrielle Hamilton has a resourceful recipe for maque choux, to serve alongside something summery, whether it’s pork burgers or grilled shrimp.
content: Good morning. Gabrielle Hamilton has a funny, wise and empathetic essay in The Times today about cooking at home during the coronavirus pandemic while married to a professional chef, while being a professional chef herself. Which is to say, it’s a story about being married, and the loving tensions that arise between spouses of different personalities during lockdown, as when your wife pulls a spongy, almost rotted red pepper out of the crisper and gently places it on the counter next to the compost bucket but not in the bucket itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Amy Julia Harris
title: ‘They Just Dumped Him Like Trash’: Nursing Homes Evict Vulnerable Residents
description: Nursing homes across the country are kicking out old and disabled residents and sending them to homeless shelters and rundown motels.
content: On a chilly afternoon in April, Los Angeles police found an old, disoriented man crumpled on a Koreatown sidewalk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Sunday: The ESPY Awards and ‘The Woods’
description: ESPN’s award show celebrates humanitarian efforts, and a Polish adaptation of Harlan Coben’s thriller comes to Netflix.
content: THE 2020 ESPY AWARDS 9 p.m. on ESPN. While other award shows have been postponed or put on hold in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic, the ESPY Awards will go on this year, but not as usual. The show, which normally celebrates the year’s top athletes and moments in athletic achievement, will instead shift its focus to honoring humanitarian stories from the sports community. The Seattle Seahawks quarterback Russell Wilson, the soccer star Megan Rapinoe and the W.N.B.A. champion Sue Bird will host the two-hour event remotely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: Tulsa, Geoffrey Berman, Father’s Day: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser, Nicole Hong and Ben Protess
title: Trump Fired Her Boss. Now She’s Taking Cases That Incensed White House.
description: Audrey Strauss has been a behind-the-scenes force in the U.S. attorney’s office in Manhattan as it pursued cases against people connected to President Trump.
content: One Friday afternoon in August of 2018, lawyers for President Trump’s longtime fixer, Michael D. Cohen, made a final bid for leniency to federal prosecutors in Manhattan. He was facing charges including that he paid hush money on Mr. Trump’s behalf to an adult film star during the 2016 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: How to Succeed in Your Office Job When There Is No Office
description: The coronavirus has many of us trying to be productive at home. Here are some tips for all of us, including our bosses.
content: The challenges of working from home are myriad. There are children to tutor, dogs to walk, shows to binge on. Hallway hellos and brainstorming at the whiteboard have given way to the stilted cadence of Zoom meetings. But three months into the work-from-home era, some best practices are emerging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: ‘Law and Order’ for ‘Blacks and Hippies’
description: Trump’s tough talk doesn’t seek to address the rage that inequity has bred, but rather to contain it.
content: Last week, Donald Trump stood in the White House Rose Garden and announced an executive order on police reform — a list of minor, unfunded actions that incentivized some changes but mandated none.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brittany Bronson
title: When Pandemic Precautions and Vegas’ Hedonism Collide
description: While gamblers refuse masks, workers fear for their safety.
content: LAS VEGAS — At the MGM’s Bellagio hotel and casino, patrons are welcomed with branded pouches stocked with hand sanitizer, face masks and a stylus they can use to push elevator buttons. At the Cosmopolitan’s elevated pool, an L.C.D. screen flashes the message, “Face masks are the new tan lines.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Teague
title: Abiding by the Confederate Flag Ban Inside Talladega, Grudgingly
description: Inside the track, racing fans went by NASCAR’s rules. Elsewhere, though, they waved the battle flag.
content: TALLADEGA, Ala. — Race fans in Alabama bristled on Sunday under NASCAR’s Confederate flag ban. But they weren’t willing to go to war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Bundesliga TV Rights Deal Suggests a Softening Market
description: The value of the broadcast rights for Germany’s top league, the first major European soccer deal agreed upon since the health crisis, fell amid concerns about the lasting damage to the global economy.
content: Germany’s top soccer league continues to be a bellwether for sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Vast Federal Aid Has Capped Rise in Poverty, Studies Find
description: But researchers caution this does not mean low-income families are escaping hardship. And they warn that when the aid expires next month, families could again be vulnerable.
content: WASHINGTON — An unprecedented expansion of federal aid has prevented the rise in poverty that experts predicted this year when the coronavirus sent unemployment to the highest level since the Great Depression, two new studies suggest. The assistance could even cause official measures of poverty to fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Annie Karni
title: The President’s Shock at the Rows of Empty Seats in Tulsa
description: Inside the campaign, advisers believe disappointing attendance at the rally shows genuine fear of the coronavirus and the reality of President Trump’s sliding poll numbers.
content: President Trump and several staff members stood backstage and gazed at the empty Bank of Oklahoma Center in horror.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Latin America Also Confronts Graft Epidemic
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 21, 2020.
content: “People are dying in the streets because the hospital system collapsed. To profit from the pain of others, with all these people who are losing their loved ones, it’s immoral.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Preston
title: Happy Father’s Day to All the Fish Dads Underwater
description: Paternal care has evolved dozens of times in aquatic life, and is more common than maternal or combined parenting.
content: A clown fish uses his fins to fan water across a glistening mass of eggs, keeping them aerated. A silver arowana scoops up his fertilized eggs with his mouth and holds them gently for two months, until a host of miniature adults swims free from his jaws. A seahorse drifts through coral, his belly pouch swollen with unborn young.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lil Baby Is Warming Up to the Spotlight
description: His protest song “The Bigger Picture” marks a high point in his evolution from reluctant up-and-comer to one of hip-hop’s reliable superstars.
content: Lil Baby began his rap career reluctantly, but in just three years has grown into an evocative and consistent hitmaker. His second studio album, “My Turn,” topped the Billboard album chart on two separate occasions, and he has become an in-demand guest artist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: September 11 Memorial Lays Off Staff Members and Furloughs Others
description: The museum and memorial complex relies on ticket receipts to pay the bills, but the pandemic has changed all that.
content: Since its subterranean galleries opened in 2014, the National September 11 Memorial & Museum in Lower Manhattan has depended upon income from millions of visitors to pay for programming, operating costs and security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kerr, Astead W. Herndon, Ben Laffin and Emily Rhyne
title: Why Trump’s Tulsa Rally Put the City’s Black Residents on Edge
description: President Trump’s rally in Tulsa, Okla., the site of one of the country’s worst episodes of racial violence in 1921, angered the city’s black residents. In this news analysis, we explain what this moment could mean for Mr. Trump’s re-election bid.
content: President Trump’s rally in Tulsa, Okla., the site of one of the country’s worst episodes of racial violence in 1921, angered the city’s black residents. In this news analysis, we explain what this moment could mean for Mr. Trump’s re-election bid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martin Gelin
title: The Pandemic Has Reshaped American Fatherhood. Can It Last?
description: Evidence from Sweden shows even short stints of time at home for fathers can have long-term consequences.
content: On his podcast, the chef David Chang recently talked about spending more time at home with his baby this spring. Mr. Chang shared stories about cooking for his son and other newfound parental responsibilities, joking that he should call the podcast “Mr. Moms.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
title: New Hope for White-Collar Job Seekers? It Depends on the Job
description: The hiring trough seems to have passed, but most opportunities are with the industries least buffeted by the coronavirus shutdown.
content: Shawn Banerji’s services do not come cheap. A top headhunter, he typically has several searches underway at once, each of which can cost the companies that hire him a six-figure retainer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Epstein Ojalvo
title: How to Manage the Emotional Impact of Getting Laid Off
description: Stop spirals before they start.
content: About a week before I was laid off for the first time, my manager assured me my job was safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iliana Magra
title: Stabbing at U.K. Park Is Declared a ‘Terrorist Incident’
description: Three people died and three were injured in the attack in Reading, England, on Saturday. Counterterrorism units will be taking over the investigation, local police said.
content: LONDON — A stabbing attack at a park in southern England that left three people dead on Saturday is being investigated as a “terrorist incident,” police officials said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: America’s Wannabe Autocrat Is in the Home Stretch. How Worried Should We Be?
description: Beware a despot when he’s cornered.
content: Two weeks ago, I wrote that perhaps, at long last, we had reached a tipping point in Trump’s popularity, and I stand by it. On Thursday, a poll conducted by Fox News (Fox!) showed him trailing Biden by 12 percentage points; the Tulsa arena hosting his comeback rally on Saturday was two-thirds empty. The man is ripe for the ultimate “Downfall” video. Especially given his recent sojourn in an actual bunker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Liverpool Draws at Everton, a Momentary Pause Before Its Party
description: A Premier League title celebration that was once years away, and then just months, now could be on in less than a week.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — By now, Liverpool has grown used to waiting. Jürgen Klopp and his team have been waiting since March to play again, to pick up where they left off. Their fans have been waiting since Jan. 19 — the day Liverpool edged Manchester United, and Anfield decided it could afford to tempt fate — for the clock to run down, the games to run out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Trump Seeks a Cultural Safe Space Amid a Deadly Pandemic
description: In his first rally since the global coronavirus pandemic suspended the campaign trail, President Trump played the hits.
content: TULSA, Okla. — The difference between a rally for Joseph R. Biden Jr. and one for President Trump starts with the attire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney and Thomas Kaplan
title: Behind Joe Biden’s Evolution on L.G.B.T.Q. Rights
description: Mr. Biden’s support for same-sex marriage in 2012 was a reversal for him and a watershed moment in his shift — and the nation’s — on L.G.B.T.Q. issues.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. voted for the Defense of Marriage Act in 1996, blocking federal recognition of same-sex marriages. Two years earlier, he voted to cut off federal funds to schools that teach the acceptance of homosexuality. In 1973, Mr. Biden, in an off-handed response to a question, wondered if homosexuals in the military or government were potential security risks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael LaForgia and Eric Schmitt
title: The Lapses That Let a Saudi Extremist Shoot Up a U.S. Navy Base
description: The gunman who killed three in Florida was not directed by Al Qaeda, nor inspired solely by online ideology. He was a new kind of terrorist, harder to spot: an extremely enterprising freelancer.
content: President Trump stepped before the cameras at a White House news conference less than a month after his inaugural and declared that he was already taking bold steps to keep “radical Islamic terrorists” out of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Luke Broadwater
title: Trump Poses ‘Danger for the Republic’ if Re-elected, John Bolton Charges
description: The president’s former national security adviser, in a TV interview, called the November election the “last guardrail” against a second term in which “there’s no telling what will happen.”
content: President Trump poses a “danger for the republic” and would be an even greater threat if he wins a second term this fall because he would be unconstrained by future electoral considerations, John R. Bolton, his former national security adviser, said in an interview aired on Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Jim Kiick, Who Helped the Dolphins Win 2 Super Bowls, Dies at 73
description: With Larry Csonka and Mercury Morris, he transformed the hapless Dolphins into a dominant team in the early 1970s.
content: Jim Kiick, one of a trio of running backs who formed the guts of the Miami Dolphins’ team that made three consecutive Super Bowl appearances in the early 1970s, died on Saturday in Wilton Manors, Fla. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: A Racist Attack on Children Was Taped in 1975. We Found Them.
description: A snippet of the documentary “Rosedale: The Way It Is” has ricocheted across the internet, upending for another generation New York City’s narrative as a bastion of tolerance.
content: The video rolls on a sunny suburban street, and a group of black children bike toward what looks to them like a parade — there’s a small crowd, and an American flag. Suddenly, they’re swarmed by a group of white children, who hurl racial epithets and rocks. Adults gathered nearby do nothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Tennessee Newspaper Apologizes for ‘Utterly Indefensible’ Anti-Muslim Ad
description: The full-page ad, which appeared in Sunday’s editions of The Tennessean and claimed “Islam” would detonate a nuclear device in Nashville, “should have never been published,” the editor said.
content: The Tennessean newspaper in Nashville is investigating how it came to publish a full-page ad on Sunday by a biblical prophecy group claiming “Islam” would detonate a bomb in the city.
source.name: The New York Times
